node.title: Some questions about the Jacobian matrix
node.bodyText: When I was doing the calculations, it reminded me of some caveats about the Jacobian matrix, and I don't know if this is something to be concerned about. If so, how should I solve this problem?

Hello
Jacobian calculation works well for kernels and boundary conditions
but this caveat is for using a User Object to contribute to the Jacobian. This is not very standard. How are you using this feature?

The ComputeGrainForceAndTorque is the one returning this warning I think.
It should be fine to use. You should just be mindful that if you use more advanced features in the same input, the combination with this experimental feature might not work as expected

Thank you for your reply, it would be great if this warning could not be paid attention to. However, the current input file can be stable for some time, and after a while the linear solver diverges, what is the problem?

see this page for more info on troubleshooting failed sovles
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/moose/application_usage/failed_solves.html

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question

 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
I followed the description for a clean new conda installation of moose, but got 12 errors upon ./run_tests referring to misc.hit_cli.-tests.
Is it possible, that there is a missing dependency in moose-dev=2024.12.02=mpich. I tried updating my conda env with an additional moose-pyhit, but the errors remain.

Apparently, because of the note on missing libwasp*.so libraray I came accross this post, with the important hint to
cd moose/framework/
git clean -xfdq

which finally let the tests pass successfully with the next execution of make -j$(nproc); ./run_tests -j$(nproc).
Somehow, I did remember to make clobberall, but not to git clean -xfdq. Still not sure, when and how often to use the latter (maybe you can comment on this ?!), but obviously I should remember this command, if something doesn't pass the tests.

�[31mmisc/hit_cli.find/parameter_exists: �[0m/home/moose/moose_beh/moose/framework/contrib/hit/hit: error while loading shared libraries: libwaspcore.so.04: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory

Yeah this is the error I get when using moose-pyhit (latest version).

Somehow, I did remember to make clobberall, but not to git clean -xfdq. Still not sure, when and how often to use the latter

You and me both 😆, I always stick to git commands. I trust git to clean a repo more than what we may have programmed into a Makefile. I also believe using git is quicker. My favorite two command to do so:
# cd ~/projects/moose
git clean -xfd
git submodule foreach --recursive git clean -xfd

node.title: How can I prevent Jacobian from updating in Newton method ?
node.bodyText: Hello. I am using the NEWTON method to solve a large deformation mechanics problem. The linear computation is very fast, and the nonlinear iteration is converging. However, for each nonlinear iteration, Jacobian is computed, which costs too much time in my case. So I am wondering if the update can be disabled, like in the modified Newton-Raphson method.

Hello
You can:

set pc reuse parameters (reuse_preconditioner)
OR
set the solve type to linear
see the executioner documentation page for the parameters

I believe that is what I am looking for. But it does not take effect.
In input file I set:
 #######################
[Preconditioning]
  [smp]
    type = SMP
    full = true
    petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type'
    petsc_options_value = 'lu'
  []
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  solve_type = NEWTON
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type'
  petsc_options_value = 'lu'
  end_time = 1
  dt = 0.1
  reuse_preconditioner = true
  reuse_preconditioner_max_linear_its = 20
[]
###############
And the output in console looks like, 

1 Nonlinear |R| = 7.962050e-06

    Computing Jacobian...                                                                [ 22.35 s] [ 2548 MB]
      0 Linear |R| = 7.962050e-06
      1 Linear |R| = 5.312515e-06
      2 Linear |R| = 1.173135e-10
      3 Linear |R| = 4.087898e-12
 2 Nonlinear |R| = 5.870031e-06
    Computing Jacobian...                                                                [ 22.25 s] [ 2560 MB]
      0 Linear |R| = 5.870031e-06
      1 Linear |R| = 5.614287e-06
      2 Linear |R| = 4.428558e-10
      3 Linear |R| = 2.125982e-11
 3 Nonlinear |R| = 3.758159e-06
    Computing Jacobian...                                                                [ 22.45 s] [ 2560 MB]
      0 Linear |R| = 3.758159e-06
      1 Linear |R| = 3.670242e-06
      2 Linear |R| = 6.633646e-10
      3 Linear |R| = 3.735210e-11

The Jacobian is still updated.

what about the linear solve_type?
we must be missing logic here, reusing the preconditioner but recomputing the Jacobian
For linear solve_type, Jacobian is computed only once for each sub step, as no nonlinear iteration is involved.

That should be the way to do it.
you could also solve with Newton still but a very tight linear convergence to make sure a second nonlinear one is not needed
But LINEAR solve_type computes Jacobian only once for each sub step, even if reuse_preconditioner is switched off. And I think LINEAR solve_type is not proper for nonlinear problems.

if you problem is nonlinear then you need to recompute the Jacobian on every nonlinear iteration.
I thoight your problem was linear from that previous post, but maybe you moved on to another one?

I am learning moose by trying different mechanics problems. I just found reuse_preconditioner does work for some models. I changed nothing but the mesh file, and then switching off reuse_preconditioner will cost about twice the time than swithing it on.
Thank you.

node.title: Issues replicating Example 1 : As Simple as it Gets with a GMSH ASCII input mesh file
node.bodyText:
I'm trying to reproduce the results of Example 1: As Simple as it Gets (link: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/examples_and_tutorials/examples/ex01_inputfile.html). Rather than using the mug.e mesh file which is provided by default, I'm trying to reproduce the figure below using a GMSH ASCII file that I created of a hollow cylinder (the .msh file is contained in here, hollow_cylinder_ascii.zip). This is the figure that I want to reproduce:

The information here on Named Entity Support (link: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/application_usage/mesh_block_type.html) has led me to believe that all I need to do is define two physical surfaces 'top' and 'bottom' that refer to the top and bottom surfaces of my cylinder. I did this in a Python script that imports the gmsh module, and you can also inspect the .msh file in hollow_cylinder_ascii.zip that these names have been implemented in lines 6 and 7 of the .msh file.
However, when I attempt to run the example problem (link: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/examples_and_tutorials/examples/ex01_inputfile.html) with ex01.i, but changing the 'Mesh' related code to the following:
[Mesh]
  # This mesh file has 'top' and 'bottom' named boundaries defined inside it.
  file = hollow_cylinder_ascii.msh
[]

I get the following error:
*** ERROR ***
/home/enk001/Documents/PHD/PHD-Code/projects-MOOSE/moose/examples/ex01_inputfile/ex01_cyl.i:26: (BCs/bottom/boundary):

:

Likewise, if I run the code with the following changes to ex01.i:
[Mesh]
  # This mesh file has 'top' and 'bottom' named boundaries defined inside it.
  file = hollow_cylinder_ascii.msh
  boundary_name = 'bottom top'
[]

I get a slightly different error:
*** ERROR ***
The following error occurred in the object "Mesh", of type "SetupMeshAction".

You must supply the same number of boundary ids and names parameters

Here are my questions: How can I get this simple example working with a .msh (ASCII) file? I believe I've correctly labelled the top and bottom surfaces of my MSH ASCII file, and the documentation here (https://mooseframework.inl.gov/application_usage/mesh_block_type.html) suggests that MOOSE should be able to recognise this?
Thanks in advance!

Hello
Please run with --mesh-only on the command line to get a summary of what MOOSE understood from this mesh file.
The second error:
You must supply the same number of boundary ids and names parameters

is because this parameter is used to (re)name boundaries that only have an id. So you must also pass the id to use this boundary_name parameter
Guillaume

How are you exporting the gmsh, @kurtenkera ? make sure you don't save all elements or parametric coordinates when exporting the mesh to .msh format.

Hi @kurtenkera. I assume your simulation is 3D. If you check the box next to 'all elements' when exporting/saving your gmsh file to .msh file, moose will select and try to use all lower-dimensional elements. You don't want to do that. That might be the cause of your issue. Yes, that's what I meant by parametric coordinates.

Hi there,
I am wondering what tool is used to create the file "mug.e".  Is it an exodus type file created by Paraview? Also, can MOOSE read any drawing files, for instance created by SolidWorks? If not, what features are available in MOOSE environment to create complex geometries.
Thanks.

I am wondering what tool is used to create the file "mug.e". Is it an exodus type file created by Paraview?

you need to use a meshing tool. This problem is very common so you ll find examples in Gmsh or Cubit

Also, can MOOSE read any drawing files, for instance created by SolidWorks

No we need to read a mesh, not a CAD file. You can use a mesher (cubit, gmsh, openfoam's hex utility, ...) to turn a CAD into a mesh

cubit open version is limited in the element count but it is definitely nicer to use
cubit paid version has no limits
Could you let me know which one (cubit or gmsh) was used to create "mug.e" file?
where is this file In moose?
~/projects/moose/examples/ex01_inputfile/mug.e

ok it doesnt say.
Either software can do it. This can be done in MOOSE too with a little bit more work

see this
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/syntax/Mesh/index.html#06c829ee-a157-4b26-9d9b-e3f359e0d061
and use the MeshGenerator objects.

node.title: Calculation of pk2_jacobian in moose
node.bodyText:
Hi @GiudGiud ,
In MOOSE, when calculating the PK2 Jacobian (C=∂S/∂E), does the framework use automatic differentiation? Specifically, if I directly compute the Second Piola-Kirchhoff stress (S) in my model, will MOOSE automatically differentiate S with respect to the Green-Lagrange strain (E) to compute the Jacobian (C)?

No that system does not use AD. It does have perfect handcoded jacobians. I am not sure what you mean by "directly computing" S. If you changed how you compute S then I think you will need to fix the pk2 jacobian too.
No I don't believe so. I would look at AnalyzeJacobian, which is give you a way to check if the Jacobian is still accurate.

Hi @maxnezdyur
Thanks for your response. I just want to clarify:  is MOOSE automatically using finite-difference approximations to compute the Jacobian (C{qp}) in this case?
Thanks in advance!
In the mean time, I am checking the link you shared
I don't see any finite differencing of C in any of the code.

You are talking about the LagrangianStress materials and UOs right?
These have coded the analytical expressions for the Jacobians. No AD or finite diffewrence.

Hi @GiudGiud
I am talking about LagrangianStress
I looked for the expression where they are calculating the pk2_jacobian but was unable to find it, although i found for pk1_jacobian which is using _C
ComputeLagrangianStressPK1.C
ComputeLagrangianStressPK2.C
Can you please let me know the file name of the expression where moose is explicitly calculating the pk2_jacobian

It should be this one
materials/lagrangian/ComputeLagrangianStressPK2.C
as the property is declared there
 _C(declareProperty<RankFourTensor>(_base_name + "pk2_jacobian"))

then computed

I’m only inputting _S[_qp] not _C[_qp]


And my model running fine


Does that means it is assuming it to be zero tensor?

no it means something is computing _C and it's somewhere in the derived class not in ComputeLagrangianStressPK2 where
computeQpPK2Stress() is a pure virtual.
For example in ComputeNeoHookeanStress you can find this computation

node.title: Preconditioning Constrained Problems.
node.bodyText:
Hi moose people, I was wondering if anyone had any tips for preconditioning constrained problems? I am currently trying to use LinearNodalConstraint in an RBE3 type fashion, and I have something that works when I use full LU in serial, but as soon as I try and use boomeramg or other preconditioners, I can't get the solve to converge.
I've tried three approaches. Full LU, which works, boomeramg on the whole matrix, which doesn't converge, and a field split approach where I've preconditioned the nodes involved in the nodal constraint with LU and everything else with boomeramg. The last approach of the three, instead of just not converging, results in negative jacobians. I've attached a repo which has input files for all three approaches and my testing mesh if anyone gets time to take a look. Otherwise, any tidbits of wisdom about preconditioning constrained problems would be extremely welcome:)
https://github.com/TheBEllis/ConstraintProblem

The last approach of the three, instead of just not converging, results in negative jacobians

A field split approach is essentially an iteration scheme, which can diverge.
How many equations do you have? Which variables? And which variables do the constraints affect?

node.title: Adaptive grid
node.bodyText:
The background is that I want to simulate the sintering of two particles. I have adopted the following mesh Settings, I hope to use adaptive mesh, but I do not know how to set, hope to get your help.

By the way, how is this uniform_refine defined, I don't seem to find an explanation of it in the help document.

Hello
Uniform refinement is a step after mesh generation where each 2D element is split in 4, and each 3D element in 8.
There's not much to explain though you can look at the code that does it lin libmesh.
Adaptive meshing should be considered once you have a working model to improve performance. You dont want to add this complexity too early.
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/syntax/Adaptivity/index.html
Thank you for your help. I think I know what to do.
